The "freedom to provide services" under TFEU article 56 applies to people who give services "for remuneration", especially commercial or professional activity. In cases where people provide services without remuneration for a commercial purpose the right does not apply, such as advertising or fundraising.

The right to withdraw services includes "to stop providing services or to discontinue offering [services] to the public" (art 6). Even if a person withdraws a commercial service such as a magazine subscription from the internet, or a webcams site, the provider of such services is not required to provide compensation, as long as the service is provided for commercial purposes. (see a list of such commercial services in [36].)

The right of access also also applies to services provided "at the request of the public" (art 6). In the case of broadcast services, access can be given only to those individuals who specifically request access (e.g., on a regular basis)

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the hippocampus are reorganized, forming new connections.

The hippocampus is also particularly important in emotional memory retention. During REM sleep where the individual is lucid yet physically asleep, memories are often recalled in a vivid and memorable fashion. This may be due to the rapid consolidation of memories into long-term memory that is preserved in the form of visual images of emotionally charged words.

Although there is considerable evidence that sleep promotes the activity of the brain's default mode network, the neuroscientists involved with the study have suggested these networks only exist during REM sleep and that activity during the rest of the sleep cycle is largely immaterial to memory consolidation. Regardless of whether memories are being formed or are already stored, the activity of these networks seems to play a role in the consolidation, the process by which new information is stored in memory.

By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike at the city, using what he would call his "Dreadnought of the Sea." He proposed sending the troops in order. The French General, Alexandre Dumouriez, was authorized to lead 2,200 soldiers, who would be reinforced over the next year to an estimated 2,600 men. The army would be commanded by a lieutenant colonel, while the commander of the city would be a Major-General. The entire army was to operate in the center of the city for the duration of the campaign, on the eastern side of the Ebro river. It took 1806 long ships and 15,000 sailors to transport the troops into this relatively thin line of trenches stretching all the way across the city from the Ebro to a point about 1/3 of a mile to the north-east of St. Mark's Cathedral.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A growth medium can have different properties, such as texture, pressure, nutrient content, temperature and pH. Microbial cells are cultured in this medium.

Stool is the first step in an animal's digestive system, and often called the animal's placenta. Once the microbial population within the stool is sufficiently colonized, nutrients are delivered and the feces are collected. The material is then either sterilized or treated with antibiotics and transported to a veterinarian.

When bacteria begin to colonize the intestinal tissue, they can cause disease symptoms. Bacteria can make their way into a person's blood, intestines, mouth or eyes, and are capable of causing severe, irreversible damage.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence on family life. The transition to adolescence is marked by more independence and an increased desire to explore the world. In a society in which children grow up surrounded by people with more education than them, it is common for such children to be raised by their grandparents, who were themselves educated to a higher level than themselves but lack the educational background to provide a well-rounded upbringing for a child. A child's relationship with his or her grandparents is particularly important to a child's development. A child's relationship with grandparents is a vital source of a child's security, and allows children to explore the possibility of forming strong emotional bonds with parents as adults. The Free Movement of Workers Regulation articles 1 to 7 set out the main provisions on equal treatment of workers. First, articles 1 to 4 generally require that employers ensure that their workers can leave their jobs freely within the same workplace. But at paragraph 25(4), the regulation says that if there are significant restrictions on this right, the employee's right will not necessarily be absolute. Article 25(4) reads:

"In the absence of measures such as those mentioned in the current article, a person who wishes to leave a job must have recourse to a process of appeal [and] to a collective and individual process."

That is, the worker may have to go through a procedure of appeal, and also could have to go through some kind of process of collective and individual appeal with the employer.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the volcanic shield).The rugged and mountainous terrain has been severely impacted by human activities and was considered the most suitable location for a volcanic research station. The island has been a research base since 1874, when the first of the five stations at the time was founded. The stations can be found in the north, south and east, and the entire island was included in the UNESCO World Heritage Site list in 1984. They argued that the university's policy of removing students solely on the basis of a finding of sexual assault was unconstitutional. Both women are still enrolled at the university. In 2013, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit found the university's policy to be constitutional, and the men were allowed to participate in Title IX proceedings. The university appealed that decision to the Supreme Court.

Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. For TCP/IP, Frame Relay is an independent layer and X.25 can be used with anything supporting TCP/IP, including software such as Internet Mail and Internet Protocol (TCP/IP).

Frame Relay uses the same hardware as a realtime clock. It is one of the first hardware hardware layers to implement time synchronisation for applications communicating over a network. Frame Relay is designed for single-sided (1.0 or 0.0) networks where the local clock is in a stable, clock-stable location on the central processor (CPU) of the OSI Model. Other OSI models use an algorithm implemented as one of the OSI layers.

A central clock is used to maintain a stable reference clock in the network. It is synchronised with the local clock by an appropriate application-provided clock

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts the view that to call oneself a part of others is offensive. An inclusive boundary, however, arises when a person sees it as valuable for him or herself to adopt the view that other people might in some circumstances regard as offensive. We can speak of such inclusive or exclusive boundaries, but we can only call one of a pair of boundaries, inclusive or exclusive, exclusive or inclusive.

Many people find it more appropriate to think of inclusive or exclusive boundaries by referring to them as "socially relevant or unproblematic." The Oxford American Dictionary cites the word "socially relevant" as "not strictly speaking irrelevant to any set of events or problems," when it is used with the word "problematic." Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and cut their beards, a practice known as kowtowing. It is the first example in a document that explicitly criminalized religious beliefs.

The edict sparked a debate within Siam's royal court about the practice of shaving. In a letter of October 3, 1594, Queen Dhanamitra wrote "the King would take this very matter in hand" if she had "no advice from the minister in her hand." A month later, King Dengyit established "the Commission to Study the Matter of The Shaving of Men's Fines in Royal Court" within his household as an impartial authority to advise him and the kingdom. Dorgon would be dismissed in 1646.
